 I think people assume they have gaydar if they can notice stereotypical mannerisms in people. For me it's been a little different. 
 
 While I was in college, I - and several of my friends (all straight, except for me- and I was out then) - hosted a perspective freshman. He was in the navy, and did a tour and was now looking to go to college. We took him out to dinner, hung out at a bar (where he hit on a couple of my female friends), and then went back to our dorms and watched movies. Nothing scandalous to write home about. At some point I decided to look around the room (giving my eyes a bit of a break), and I noticed that the Navy guy had fallen asleep. As I looked at him, "he's gay" just popped in my head for the briefest of moments, but I shook it off. I don't even know why I thought it, since I didn't even think he was attractive.
 
 Six months later, I ran into him at a gay club in Boston, lip-locked with some random guy.
 
 There was another incident where this guy had a twin whom he wanted to work at our company. I saw him chatting up the receptionist and I so happened to comment to a coworker that I was with, "wouldn't it be funny if he were the gay twin?"
 
 I ran into him at another gay club a week later.
 
 Another gentleman who was hired at the company, had to share an office with me for about 3 months. Considering that we were too busy to stay in one place, it wasn't much of an issue, but there were moments when would chit chat about mundane stuff. He even told me about his girlfriend a couple of times. At some point I kept getting a nagging feeling that he was gay. I even asked another gay person (the twin) if he sensed it too. The twin asked me if he did or said anything to me (he hadn't), since he couldn't see it. I just kept having a nagging feeling.
 
 Well, there was a party, and things happened, and I ended up having to take him home (he was drunk, and I need to make sure he wasn't taken advantage of) and had a little talk about what I had witnessed. Now I see him out all the time.
 
 I would say that I have gaydar. However, for it to work for me, I cannot look for mannerisms. I also cannot have any suggestions that a person may be gay. It just has to happen on its own, while doing everyday things. When it's not suggested, I am dead on.

 I never once mentioned this to my husband. I was ashamed of my feelings and couldn't talk about it to anyone. 
 It took me years after the end of my marriage to resolve these issues and accept who I am, be comfortable in my own skin and start learning to actually like myself for who I am. I had to learn to stop punishing myself, stop telling myself how sick or bad I was. 
 Only once I was able to do that was I ever able to actually find happiness. 
 I found out that not only could I learn to love myself, but someone else was able to love me too. I found that my family still loved me, and even more so for being honest with myself. 
 I have a wonderful partner, a supportive family and a happy child. 
 All I don't have are the benefits and securities which I had when I was married to a man. 
 
 My ex gets to go off and marry four times before he turned thirty without even a second glance by the government, but if I dare to find just one person whom I want to spend the rest of my life with, whom I want to grow old with, whom shares in raising my son, I am condemned to be concidered as a second class citizen? 
 
 I'm sorry, but I joined the Navy because I believed in my country. I believed in it's fairness and took an oath to protect those freedoms for every citizen. 
 But the irony is, I don't get those very same rights of which I took an oath to preserve. 
 That's not democracy, that's not equality, that's just not the country I was raised to believe in. 
 
 ...it's that knowledge which drives me. Because it affects me on such a personal level.
 
 I know you can't sympathize, but I can only hope that you are intellegent enough to at least understand even some part of what I and so many fellow citizens are going through. How so many families are put in perril because of this very divisive and descriminatory state of affairs. 
 
 Tomarrow (well today actually) I will be talking to a group of fellow citizens, along with my partner and a few others, about why this is so important to myself, my partner and our family. 
 Why our children and our children's children will only benefit from complete access to equality.

In point of fact, I seldom think much about it except when it comes up in forums such as this. They so often degenerate into accusations and venom that I tune out early.

 I've noticed in my own life as a male that I can communicate better with women than I can with men. It is also true that most men do not have friends like women do. You didn't get a sympathetic ear to pour out your feelings and this may have had a part in your finally coming clean and making the break with the past and embracing a full lesbian lifestyle. Rejection or the fear of rejection can have a marked effect on a person's psyche. I wonder what you might have had if you had a more understanding husband who were as willing to communicate with you as your female friends will.

In point of fact, I seldom think much about it except when it comes up in forums such as this. They so often degenerate into accusations and venom that I tune out early.

 
 Well yes, I was wording it in that manor as to distinguish between empathy and sympathy. I know you cannot sympathize, but empathy was never assumed to not be there. :) 
 
 
You say that you never once mentioned this to your husband. I wonder if he was one who you were unable to communicate with. From your description it sounds like he isn't exactly the most stable of individuals with four marriages.

 
 You know, I really don't bother to try to rationalize or even analyze it anymore. Why bother? I mean, the point still remains, I'm gay, our marriage didn't last. And in my book, it's a good thing too. 
 No, he wasn't all that stable. He bounced around from bed to bed. But years later I had a discussion with him, well kind of one sided, and I told him: "Look, you say you love your son. So, I'm telling you this. Either make this latest marriage work, or I don't want you to have anymore to do with MY son. He doesn't need that kind of influence in his life." 
 I guess he took it to heart and his fourth marriage seems to be the charm. At least it works for him. I personally don't get it, but whatever...
 
 
 
I've noticed in my own life as a male that I can communicate better with women than I can with men. It is also true that most men do not have friends like women do. You didn't get a sympathetic ear to pour out your feelings and this may have had a part in your finally coming clean and making the break with the past and embracing a full lesbian lifestyle.

 
 Gotta stop you there. I really resent the term "lifestyle" as if it's about the clothes I wear or the car I drive. It's not a lifestyle, it's simply part of my life, part of what makes me who I am. 
 And I reject the notion that because my marriage failed that I was somehow so broken up over it I rejected more men. 
 No, I simply gave me the opportunity to reflect on what I wanted from life. Did I want to continue living a lie (knowing that I would be ultimately teaching my son to lie) or did I want to accept myself for who I always knew I was and deal with reality by living honestly. 
 
 You see, I was faced with a moral dilema. 
 It wasn't about me alone anymore. It was about my son and what kind of role model I was to be for him. As a mother, my life was no longer about "me, me, me" but rather about what was I ultimately teaching my child. How could I expect to raise a good man, if he learned by the examples of his parents that women were objects to be used and thrown out when no longer wanted or needed? 
 I chose to be the better role model. I chose to not live a lie, to set the example that one must be honest with themselves before one could be expected to be honest with those around him/her. 
 
 
 Rejection or the fear of rejection can have a marked effect on a person's psyche. I wonder what you might have had if you had a more understanding husband who were as willing to communicate with you as your female friends will.

 
 I really doubt it. Because I was not being honest myself. So, it was moreover my lack of being able to communicate. If I could not be honest with myself, how could I ever expect honesty in return? 
 Yes, everyone has a fear of rejection, to some extent or another, but you cannot deny that my "coming out" was a real test of that rejection reaction. I took a HUGE risk in learning to be honest. 
 No, the fear of rejection was not my problem in my choosing to no longer be with men, but rather the other way around. My fear of rejection pushed me to live in direct opposition of who I really am. My fear of rejection by my family, my friends, society in general pushed me to believe that if I was with a man I would be accepted and I would somehow miraculously be "cured." 
 It didn't work. One cannot live a lie and not expect it to have a detrimental effect on one's life. My lie caused me a lot of pain, until I rejected the lie, accepted truth and stopped being affraid. 
 Only once I was able to do that was I able to find true acceptance from those who mattered the most, my family, my friends, my own son.

 I like to think I have a unique perspective. I've lived attempting to act straight, been legally married and served my country. I know all too well what I am being denied as a citizen.

 I can see, maybe because I am a mother, what the effects on children are when we teach them to lie or to cheat.

I've noticed in my own life as a male that I can communicate better with women than I can with men. 

 
 Some things about attidudes toward male/male and male/female relationships puzzle me. 
 
 First of all, the non-communicative male is an American subspecies. European men, by and large, actually TALK to their male friends. Even about important stuff. (Some Americans do as well, of course, but it's supposedly quite rare among straight guys. Heck, even I'm pretty clammed up much of the time.)
 
 Secondly, opponents to same-sex marriage always bring up the "complimentarity" issue -- men and women being made for each other, etc. Beyond the "plumbing" argument -- tab A / slot B stuff -- it seems to make little sense in a culture that spends so much time pointing out that men and women don't (or can't) understand each other. Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus... so you'd think most people could see that two Martians would get along pretty well. Same for two Venusians. To say nothing about the cool spaceships and the x-ray vision!!!

 I guess that just makes me really strange, both in personality and experience. I guess it's the kind of people I know. I find theatre people to be very open about a lot. Even stuff you don't want to know. I think it has a lot to do with the fact that actors tend to pull from life experience as well as emotions thought to be lost to pull off a performance. Also the fact that you're bombarded with human sexuality and body types in the dressing rooms. Actors, at least backstage, tend to be a lot less uptight about things. 
 
 I was on general cast for a local Renaissance Faire for eight years. There's really not a whole lot of "privacy" to be had there. Everyone comes to their pre-show cast meetings with little else on but their underwear...if you're lucky. We're all trapsing around carrying our huge costumes and begging anyone with a pair of free hands to sinch you into your corset. (Yeah some men too have to wear those tourture divices...)
 So, here you are, in the middle of the woods, surrounded by other half naked people all trying to squeeze into these elaborite costumes/garb. (at least those of us who were in "court"). It truly leaves very little to the imagination.

 This was something that I learned a few years back. I read somewhere that men don't really have friends as adults and then I thought about myself and realized it was true. We do talk to one another but we don't really confide and comfort one another as women do. I think that's why men don't live as long as women. When we get on in years and lose our spouses or whatever we tend to become isolated and prone to illnesses and hopelessness that women don't have. They more or less assume they will outlive their spouses and have a reservoir of friends among their women friends. They can talk for hours on the phone. When's the last time a man would do that? That's not to put women down but there is a distinct difference. And I've found that I can talk to women, even on private matters, that I would never share with other men. A few years back my wife had a serious illness and I never felt so alone in my life. I didn't have that support system and I suspect most men don't either. Fortunately she did recover her health but that was a real eye-opener for me. Men may be much stronger physically, but emotionally much less secure.
